thread.title: Labour see off Conservative advances and strengthen grip on County Durham

author: Laura Hill
title: Labour see off Conservative advances and strengthen grip on County Durham
text:
News Labour see off Conservative advances and strengthen grip on County Durham Just one Labour MP saw their share of the vote fall in the County which has long been a heartland for Labour Share Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
Labour have managed to see off Tory advances and increase their number of votes in almost every seat in County Durham . 
Despite the Conservatives desperately chasing seats in the county Labour increased their grasp on the North East heartlands. 
Just one of the county’s MPs had reason to worry when the ballots were counted. 
Bishop Auckland MP Helen Goodman held onto her seat by the skin of her teeth with just 502 votes between her and Conservative candidate Christopher Adams. 
Although she saw her majority fall from 11,439 in 2015, the anti-Corbyn MP who has represented the area for 12 years said voters opted against Theresa May’s Tories rather than for Jeremy Corbyn’s Labour. 
The Tories campaigned hard in the rural seat, sending Boris Johnson to support Conservative candidate Christopher Adams days before voters headed to the polls, a move Ms Goodman said backfired. 
She said: “The Conservative candidate was let down by the foreign secretary whose visit put a rocket boost under the Labour vote.” Laura Pidcock elected North West Durham MP with her mum and dad (Photo: Newcastle Chronicle) 
Conservatives also had their sights set on Tony Blair’s old constituency of Sedgefield, along with North West Durham . 
Newly elected MP Laura Pidcock, won 5,234 more votes than her predecessor Pat Glass who stood down. 
The 29-year-old said: “We won this seat because we fought with really hard work - hope, determination and I just want to say to the people out there who are suffering, really suffering, under Conservative rule - the tide is turning.” 
Phil Wilson, dubbed by some as Blair’s heir, fought off the Tories and kept his symbolic seat with a 6,059 majority. 
He said: “The Conservatives put a lot more effort into the seat than in previous years. They obviously thought they had a chance, they were after the symbolic nature of the seat.” Read More 
He slammed Theresa May and arrogant but stopped short of throwing his weight behind his party’s leader. 
“It is one thing to campaign and another thing to govern,” he said. 
In North Durham Kevan Jones kept the seat he has held since 2001 with a comfortable 13,000 majority. 
Attacking Theresa May he said: “Theresa May’s gamble to call this election has completely failed and one other thing shown is the last seven years of austerity, which has damaged not only this constituency but constituencies across the country - has also been rejected.” Grahame Morris (Photo: Newcastle Chronicle) 
The former pit villages of Easington have been represented by Labour since 1950 and this election was no exception with MP Grahame Morris winning with a 14,892 majority. 
A Corbynite through and through Mr Morris said: “Isn’t it just a lovely feeling when you win and are on a crest of a wave.” 
In Durham City Labour MP Roberta Blackman-Woods changed her tune on Corbyn after seeing a huge increase in young people engaged in politics during this campaign. 
“I was critical of Jeremy over Brexit but I did go back and support him,” she said. 
“Young people in particular are very taken by Jeremy.” Bishop Auckland Result: Labour HOLD 
Helen Goodman (LAB) 20, 808 
Christopher Adams (CON) 20,306 
Ciaran Morrissey (LIB DEM) 1,176 
Adam Walker (BNP) 991 Durham City result: Labour HOLD 
Roberta Blackman-Woods (LAB) 26,772 
Amanda Hopgood (LIB DEM) 4,787 
Malcolm Bint (UKIP) 1,116 
Jon Collings (Young People Party) 45 
John Elmer (Green) 797
